description: A respelling of puisne, from Anglo-Norman puisné (“later, more recent; junior; weakly”) [and other forms] and Middle French puisné (“born after (a specified person); younger, youngest; one who is born after (a specified person)”) (modern French puîné (“cadet (born after a sibling); a cadet (someone born after a sibling)”)), from puis (“after; since”) + né (“born”). Puis is derived from Old French pois (“after; since”), from Vulgar Latin *postius (“afterward”), from Latin posteā (“afterwards; hereafter; thereafter; next, then”), from post (“after; since”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *pós (“afterwards”)) + ea (“these (things)”); and né from Latin nātus (“born”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵenh₁- (“to beget; to give birth; to produce”).

entries.meaning: Of inferior significance, size, or strength; ineffective, small, weak. [from 16th c.]
examples: You puny earthlings are no match for Ming the Merciless!

entries.meaning: (chiefly Southern US, south Midland US) (Frequently) ill; poorly, sickly. [from 18th c.]
Inferior in rank; specifically, of a judge: junior. [16th–19th c.]
Coming later in time; secondary, subsequent. [17th c.]
(archaic) An inferior person; a subordinate; also, an insignificant person. [from 16th c.]
examples: (inferior person): Synonyms: inferior, junior, (obsolete) puisne, underling, vassal ·   Antonym: superior
(insignificant person): Synonyms: see Thesaurus:nonentity, Thesaurus:worthless person ·   Antonyms: see Thesaurus:important person

entries.meaning: A younger person; a junior. [16th–17th c.]

examples: Synonyms: newb, rookie, tenderfoot; see also Thesaurus:beginner

entries.meaning: A person who is not experienced; a beginner, a novice. [16th–18th c.]
examples: Synonyms: newb, rookie, tenderfoot; see also Thesaurus:beginner

entries.meaning: (law) A puisne or junior judge. [16th–17th c.]
(university slang, law) A new student at a school, university, the Inns of Court, etc.; a junior. [16th–17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: fresher, freshman, new bug, (Tonbridge School) novi, (Westminster School) shadow
